Patch Set 2:

just to keep a record here is the IRC convo we had

<zzzeek> dansmith: the basic idea is do that UPDATE and then get the rowcount back for numnber of rows affected
<dansmith> abhishekk: ah sorry
<zzzeek> if it's zero, you missed
<zzzeek> does that make sense ?
<dansmith> zzzeek: meaning my example SQL update query you mean right?
<zzzeek> yes
<abhishekk> dansmith, no problem
<zzzeek> I would skip the ORM and just run result = connection.execute(table.updat()...)
<zzzeek> then result.rowcount
<dansmith> zzzeek: yeah, okay that's what I thought.. I don't really know how to translate that into ORM stuff, but maybe I can work on that a bit and get you to validate that what I'm doing is legit?
<dansmith> zzzeek: suhweet, that's what I'd rather do
<zzzeek> dansmith: yeah I would just use a core statement
<dansmith> zzzeek: a dedicated claim() operation and just do it that way
<zzzeek> dansmith: just for the claim part at least.  then once oyu have it you can do wahever ORM things
<dansmith> yep
<zzzeek> dansmith: also if you have an ORM session, you can get the connection for the transaciton as conn = session.connection()
<dansmith> zzzeek: don't we want to do that update thing outside a transaction where we have already read some of the data we'll be examining?
<zzzeek> dansmith: hmmmm yes if oyu are on repeatable read then I guess so
<dansmith> I thought if we did it with other stuff, we'd be operating on repeated read data... yeah that
<zzzeek> might not matter
<zzzeek> the other transacvtions would block
<dansmith> so I figured we'll just do the claim as a single shot thing, which is fine because the real work happens later in an async task
<zzzeek> sure I guess commit is safer b.c. then it goes out and gets past the locks but also does the galera writeset thing
<zzzeek> it's just when you do work subsequent to that, you want to have a new transaction
<zzzeek> so if this is the very fisrt thing you're doing it should be OK
<dansmith> ack okay
<zzzeek> assuming this table is also involved in the subseqeunt work
<dansmith> zzzeek: I need to look at their stuff more to be able to answer that question, but .. probably
<zzzeek> its just cleaner to have two serial transactions rather than one oingoing and another pops out in the middle
<abhishekk> dansmith, this solution will also solve our race?
<dansmith> so abhishekk I will try to work on this claim thing, zzzeek can check my work and or make fun of it if it's wrong and then we can use it to solve your race
<dansmith> zzzeek: yep, two is what I'm going for
<abhishekk> dansmith, ack :D
<abhishekk> dansmith, back to our staging clearing solution
<zzzeek> when transactions overlap that's how you can get deadlocks so keep them serial is simpler
* priteau has quit (Remote host closed the connection)
<dansmith> zzzeek: ++
<zzzeek> ok i will copy gthis to the gerrit as a record

Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Tests look a lot better now, thanks. I think you can still leak your lock in some places. Since it's not user- or admin-resolvable, or even discoverable since the property is hidden, it seems like great care should be taken to make sure we don't get the image stuck, right?

Patch Set 10:

Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

My -1 is for both breaking the API contract for the other methods and that this has its own race condition.

I don't really like the time-of-day approach to breaking the lock, but if that's the desired resolution then that's fine. I think that 30 minutes of unexplained Conflict is enough time to call the admins, and a day of unexplained Conflict after a system reboot is enough time to file a bug with support. It seems to me like there really needs to be a glance-manage command to bust the lock if you just rebooted after a power outage and don't want to way 23 hours to touch your image again (which kinda defeats the point of the timer anyway).

What other methods this approach is breaking? I think I'm missing something.

So the reason why there is no glance-manage tool for this, nor client patch, nor doc change explaining those timeouts or test changes to even relate to this PS is what you say you have found. Something we missed that this approach would break. I'm looking forward to hear what that is before taking the time to attack those. Thus the "WIP:" flag

 > just rebooted after a power outage and don't want to way 23 hours
 > to touch your image again (which kinda defeats the point of the
 > timer anyway).

What is your SLA? Yes, if you need and expect it being solved in 2hrs probably it's good time to nag to the admins to take an action and break it manually after. If the SLA is "we get to it when we get to it" and it's inconvenience that it won't happen today (or there is 2000 images in same state and it just takes a while to get through them) a way to get around it might be handy. Is it 4, 8, 12, 24 hours Happy to take feedback. 24hours just was pretty much safe bet that something is already seriously wrong if importing to single store takes more than that and easier to test the concept with than 3hrs 27min 18sec. Configurable? Does it need to be? I'd prefer not, but if so we can look into that.

Okay, so there will be a glance command forthcoming to bust the timed lock? If so, that's cool, although I would argue that the best plan is to forego the time-based lock and just let an admin bust the lock after a system failure if necessary. The taskflow stuff should ensure that the lock is cleaned up after any failure where we are able to reasonably handle cleanup. But, that's MHO as I stated.

 > What is your SLA? Yes, if you need and expect it being solved in
 > 2hrs probably it's good time to nag to the admins to take an action

 > with than 3hrs 27min 18sec. Configurable? Does it need to be? I'd
 > prefer not, but if so we can look into that.

I don't want it to be configurable either, because if people set it to be too low, it will break in ways they will almost surely not understand. That's why I'd rather it not be time-based at all :)

Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

I feel like we're probably getting to the point where we're no longer discussing actual technical problems and solutions that address the problem. So let me make a couple of new suggestions:

1. We were originally using the task id as the value for the lock, which eliminates the need to use something else, like time-of-day, and which means we can hold the lock the whole time. You objected to that because it involved the API setting the lock to the task ID before the task was running and thus the revert()s may never get called to clean that up, leaving the cryptic value in the lock key that isn't validate-able. What if we used the request-id? That would (a) be the API setting a value that is clearly the business of the API, (b) be something the client could look at to know if it was at least selected for the single import task slot, (c) be something we can set and leave to avoid unsetting the lock temporarily and/or worrying about the updated time, and (d) be something that the operator could use with logs to determine if it's safe to bust the lock after a failure. It would not make automatic clean-up better, but maybe it's enough of a compromise to be something everyone can get on board with?

2. We could let admins bust the lock via the API, if a couple of conditions are true. First, the copy process could continually touch a status file in the staging directory to indicate liveness. I believe Abhi said that the staging area has to be shared between all the workers because the import is a multi-stage process anyway, so this should work. AFAIK, the staging area is always just a filesystem. If the task stops and the mtime of the status file is more than something like 30 minutes old, then the API will allow the admin to bust it by just deleting the property. That would also give us an option to return "304: There are 7 minutes left on the lock" status to the admin, and also provides a concrete way to bust the lock in situations where things have died.
